questions.text: Which of the following is an example of a ​pneumatic bone?
questions.solution:
The maxilla is a pneumatic bone. 

Pneumatic bones contain air-filled cavities, which make them light-weight. They also aid in the resonance of sound and act as air conditioning chambers for inspired air. E.g., Maxilla, sphenoid, ethmoid, etc. 

Carpal bones and tarsal bones are short bones. 

Sternum, ribs, scapula, and bones of the skull vault are flat bones.

Hip bones, vertebra, and bones in the base of the skull are irregular bones.

questions.text: Two-cell—two-gonadotropin hypothesis is _________

choices.text: FSH and LH inhibits the release of estrogen and progesterone
FSH acts on granulosa cells and LH on theca cells
FSH stimulates estrogen while LH inhibits estrogen
FSH feedback inhibits hypothalamus while LH feedback inhibits pituitary

questions.solution:
The two-cell—two-gonadotropin hypothesis.

  • Estradiol synthesis requires the contribution of two distinct cell types:
    • The theca and granulosa cells within the follicle and
    • The theca-lutein and granulosa lutein cells within the corpus luteum
  • The follicular theca cells, under the control of LH, produce androgens that diffuse to the follicular granulosa cells, where they are converted to estrogens via an FSH-supported aromatization reaction. The granulosa cells cannot convert progesterone to androstenedione because of the lack of the enzyme 17α-hydroxylase.

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes takes part in substrate level phosphorylation in glycolysis?
questions.solution:
The enzyme involved in substrate level phosphorylation is pyruvate kinase.

In substrate-level phosphorylation, there is a direct generation of ATP. In glycolysis, there are two such reactions, which are examples of substrate-level phosphorylation.

They are as follows:

  • 1, 3 bisphosphoglycerate to 3 phosphoglycerate, catalyzed by the enzyme phosphoglycerate kinase.
  • Phosphoenol pyruvate to pyruvate, catalyzed by pyruvate kinase.

questions.text: A 36-year-old male presented with skin-coloured umbilicated nodules. Microscopy is as shown below. The most likely diagnosis is______.
questions.solution:
The given microscopic image shows large, ellipsoid, homogeneous, cytoplasmic inclusion in cells of the stratum granulosum and the stratum corneum classically seen in molluscum contagiosum.

Molluscum contagiosum is a common, self-limited viral disease of the skin caused by a poxvirus. Poxvirus is brick-shaped and is the largest pathogenic poxvirus in humans.

Individual lesions are firm, pruritic, and pink to skin-coloured umbilicated papules. A curd-like material can be expressed from the central umbilication

Tzanck smear: intracytoplasmic molluscum bodies (Henderson–Patterson bodies), the largest known inclusion bodies.

Microscopic examination: Cuplike verrucous epidermal hyperplasia and Molluscum bodies: large, ellipsoid, homogeneous, cytoplasmic inclusion in cells of the stratum granulosum and the stratum corneum.

Molluscum bodies contain numerous virions.

questions.text: The autoimmune disease  shown in the image involves ___________ hypersensitivity.
questions.solution:
The disease shown in the image is mysthenia gravis. It is an example of Type II hypersensivity.

Type II hypersensitivity reaction is mediated by antibodies directed towards antigen or cell surface or extracellular matrix.

questions.text: Antacid that can typically cause diarrhea is ___________
questions.solution:
Magnesium salts have a laxative property and can cause diarrhea.

Aluminium salts can cause constipation by relaxing smooth muscles and magnesium salts have the action opposite to aluminium. The combination of aluminum and magnesium salts can neutralize each other’s action,thus the combination is preferred.

questions.text: A 33-year-old man who was found dead in his home was taken for a postmortem examination. It revealed clogging of the respiratory tract by semi-digested food particles consisting of rice and vegetable matter. This would fall under which of the following?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of aspiration of food particles known as choking. It is classified under mechanical asphyxia.

Mechanical asphyxia can be classified depending on the respiratory block:

  1. Compression / constriction of the neck - Hanging, strangulation, throttling
  2. Blocking external orifices of respiration, i.e. mouth and/or nostrils - Smothering, overlying, suffocation, gagging
  3. Impaction of foreign bodies in respiratory tract - Choking
  4. Compression and mechanical fixation of the chest and abdomen preventing the respiratory movements - Traumatic asphyxia / crush asphyxia
  5. Inhalation of fluid into the respiratory tract - Drowning

questions.text: The only abductor of the vocal cord is ______
questions.solution: Posterior cricoarytenoid is the only intrinsic muscle of the larynx that causes abduction of vocal cords.

questions.text: Identify the pathology in the below image.
questions.solution:
The image depicts a bacterial corneal ulcer with hypopyon.

Hypopyon in a bacterial ulcer:

  • It is due to the outpouring of leucocytes from the vessels and their gravitation to the bottom of the anterior chamber to form a hypopyon.
  • Sterile: Consists of leucocytes
  • Mobile

questions.text: Identify the species of mosquito shown in the image below
questions.solution: • The given image of a mosquito belonging to the Aedes species. It can be identified with the stripes on the legs and body. They are also called tiger mosquitoes because of their stripped patterns.

questions.text: Which of the following gives the approximate magnitude of completed family size?
questions.solution:
Total fertility rate gives the approximate magnitude of completed family size.

Total Fertility Rate

  • It represents the average number of children a woman would have if she were to pass through her reproductive years bearing children at the same rates as the women in each age group now.
  • It is the sum of all age specific fertility rates multiplied by 5.
  • This measure gives the approximate magnitude of completed family size.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about par boiling?

choices.text: Parboiling refers to partial cooking of rice in steam
The hot soaking process is used for par boiling.
Vitamins and minerals are driven into endosperm due to par boiling.
Par boiling softens the rice grains and makes it resistant to insects.

questions.solution:
Par boiling hardens the rice grains (not softens) and makes it resistant to insects.

Par boiling:

Par boiling is the process of partial cooking of rice in steam.

The hot soaking process is used for par boiling and it was developed by the Central Food Technological Research Institute (CFTRI), Mysore.

It preserves the nutritive quality of rice as during the process, vitamins and minerals in the outer aleurone layer are driven into inner endosperm.

The advantages are:

  • Preserves nutritive quality
  • Hardens the grains
  • Makes the rice grains insect resistant

questions.text: What is least likely to be seen in a patient suspected of COVID-19?
questions.solution:
Lymphocytosis is least likely to be seen in a patient with COVID-19. On the contrary, lymphopenia is likely to be seen. 

Common laboratory abnormalities seen in COVID-19 are:

  • Lymphopenia
  • Mild thrombocytopenia
  • Elevated aminotransaminase levels
  • Elevated lactate dehydrogenase levels
  • Elevated inflammatory markers - eg, ferritin, C-reactive protein, and erythrocyte sedimentation rate
  • Markers of a hypercoagulable state - high fibrinogen, high D-dimer levels, increased fibrin degradation products, prolonged prothrombin time (PT) and activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) 

The degree of these abnormalities tends to correlate with disease severity.

questions.text: Interpret the given ECG:
questions.solution:
The above ECG shows a complete heart block.

Features in the ECG supporting the diagnosis of complete heart block:

  • PP interval is constant
  • RR interval is constant
  • P waves more in number than QRS complexes
  • There is no relation between P waves and the QRS complexes.

For a second-degree heart block, the QRS complex should be preceded by the P wave, whereas in a third-degree heart block, the QRS complex is independent of the P wave.

The ECG features are marked in the image below:

Related Pearl: Types of Heart block

questions.text: Which of the following features would you not expect to see in patients with Parkinson’s disease?
questions.solution:
Exaggerated deep tendon reflexes are not a feature of Parkinson's disease. Cardinal motor features in PD include:

  • Resting tremors
  • Bradykinesia
  • Rigidity
  • Gait disturbance / postural instability

Mnemonic: TRAP - Tremors + Rigidity + Akinesia + Postural instability

  • Other motor features include:
    • Micrographia
    • Masked facies (hypomimia)
    • Reduced eye blinking
    • Soft voice (hypophonia)
    • Dysphagia
  • Non-motor features are:
    • Anosmia
    • Sensory disturbance (pain)
    • Mood Disorders (depression)
    • Sleep disturbances (rapid eye movement behavior disorder)
    • Autonomic:
      • GI disturbances
      • Genitourinary disturbances
      • Sexual dysfunction
      • Orthostatic hypotension
    • Cognitive impairment

Parkinson’s disease(PD) is the second most common neurodegenerative disorder after Alzheimer's disease. UK Brain Bank criteria is used for the diagnosis of PD.

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in tumor lysis syndrome?
questions.solution:
Hypocalcemia, not hypercalcemia, is seen in tumour lysis syndrome (TLS). 

It is caused by the destruction of a large number of rapidly proliferating neoplastic cells. It most commonly occurs after the initiation of chemotherapy. It is characterized by:

  • Hyperuricemia
  • Hyperkalemia
  • Hyperphosphatemia
  • Hypocalcemia 
  • Acidosis
  • Acute renal failure

The management of TLS includes:

  • Aggressive hydration
  • Allopurinol 
  • Urinary alkalinization with sodium bicarbonate(Only advisable if rasburicase is not readily available. The level of calcium should be serially monitored)
  • Rasburicase - recombinant urate oxidase.

questions.text: During an intra-oral procedure, the resident uses the given suture material to place sutures on the soft palate. What is this suture material called?
questions.solution:
The suture material shown in the image is plain catgut. It is a yellowish absorbable suture material. 

Chromic catgut is brownish in colour.

Vicryl is a violet-coloured absorbable suture material.

Silk is a black-coloured, multifilament, natural, braided, and non-absorbable suture material. It is derived from the cocoon of the silkworm larva.

Prolene is a blue coloured, monofilament, non-absorbable suture.

Related Pearl: Suture materials

Suture Types Uses

Absorbable suture materials
Catgut Plain/Chromic

Ligate superficial vessels

Suture subcutaneous tissues, stomas and other tissues that heal rapidly
Polyglactin (Vicryl) Braided multifilament

Gut and biliary anastomoses

Vascular ligatures

Kidney and ureter surgeries.

Subcuticular wound

Polydioxanone

Monofilament

Dyed or undyed

Used in tissues where slightly longer wound support is required

Poliglecaprone (Monocryl)

 Monofilament

Subcuticular suturing of skin

Soft tissue ligation

Gastrointestinal and muscle surgery
Non-absorbable suture materials
Silk

Braided or twisted multifilament

Coated (with wax or silicon) or uncoated

Ligation and suturing when long-term tissue support is necessary

e.g., for securing drains externally, two-layer bowel anastomoses

Surgical steel

Monofilament or multifilament

Closure of sternotomy wounds
Nylon

Monofilament or braided multifilament

Skin closure

Abdominal wall closure

Hernia repair

Neurosurgery

Polybutester

Monofilament

Exhibits elasticity. Favoured for use in plastic surgery
 

Polypropylene (Prolene)

 Monofilament   

Cardiovascular surgery and vascular anastomosis 

Plastic surgery

General surgical subcuticular skin closure

questions.text: Which of the following is the earliest sign in Crohn's disease?
questions.solution:
Aphthous ulcers, surrounded by a rim of erythematous mucosa, are the earliest lesions seen in a patient with Crohn's disease during endoscopy.

Crohn's colitis usually spares the rectum and is most severe in the cecum and right colon. In early Crohn's disease, small, punched-out aphthous ulcers are often seen (the result of submucosal lymphoid follicle expansion). In moderate disease, the aphthous ulcers coalesce into larger ulcers, which may take on the appearance of a star (stellate ulcers). As disease severity increases, submucosal edema and injury can result in cobblestoning of the mucosa and eventually the formation of serpiginous ulcers, which are typical findings in Crohn's disease. 

Related Pearl: Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD)

questions.text: A patient was evaluated for dysphagia, and barium swallow shows the following image. The probable diagnosis is ________
questions.solution:
The image shows a corkscrew esophagus, which is seen in diffuse esophageal spasm.

Diffuse Esophageal Spasm - It is a hypermotility disorder of the esophagus seen more commonly in women.  Patients usually present with dysphagia and chest pain which is caused by spontaneous, abnormal contractions seen more in the distal two-thirds of the oesophageal body. However, in between the contractions, peristalsis remains normal. Pathologically, there is marked hypertrophy of the circular muscles.

A barium swallow shows a corkscrew esophagus. However, manometry is the gold standard test for diagnosis. Simultaneous, multi-peaked contractions of high amplitude (>120 mmHg) or long duration (>2.5 seconds) are suggestive of DES (as given in the question).

Treatment: Calcium-channel antagonists, vasodilators, and endoscopic dilatation have only transient effects. Surgical treatment includes extended/long oesophageal myotomy, up to the aortic arch, if required. The surgical treatment of DES is more successful in improving dysphagia than chest pain.

questions.text: Budd-Chiari syndrome is due to thrombosis of the _______.
questions.solution:
Budd–Chiari syndrome (BCS) is an uncommon congestive hepatopathy characterized by the obstruction of hepatic venous outflow.

Types: 

  • Primary  Budd–Chiari syndrome: when the obstructive process involves an endoluminal venous thrombosis.
  • Secondary Budd–Chiari syndrome:  when the veins are compressed or invaded by a neighboring lesion originating outside the vein.

Most common presentation: ascites and abdominal discomfort.

Abdominal ultrasonography is the initial investigation of choice and can demonstrate the absence of hepatic vein flow, spider web hepatic veins, and collateral hepatic veins.

The definitive radiographic study is hepatic venography to determine the presence and extent of hepatic vein thrombus as well as measure inferior vena cava (IVC) pressures.

Hepatic scintigraphy shows a "central hot spot" due to healthy hypertrophied caudate lobe.

Treatment:

  • Initial treatment consists of  medically managing the underlying disease process and preventing extension of the hepatic vein thrombosis through systemic anticoagulation.
  • The associated portal hypertension and ascites is managed in a manner similar to that in most cirrhotic patients.
  • Radiologic and surgical intervention should be reserved for patients whose condition is nonresponsive to medical therapy. Percutaneous angioplasty and transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPS), in combination with thrombolytic therapy, are the preferred strategies to restore the outflow of blood from the liver.
  • Surgical shunting, particularly with the side-to-side portacaval shunt,  turns the portal vein into a hepatic outflow tract.

questions.text: The bivalent vaccine against Human papilloma virus serotypes is ______
questions.solution:
Bivalent vaccine against HPV 16 and 18 is known as Cervarix. Cervarix is given at 0, 1 and 6 months.

Quadrivalent vaccine against HPV 6, 11, 16 and 18 is known as Gardasil or Silgard is given at 0, 2 and 6 months.

Nonavalent vaciine against HPV 6, 11, 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52 and 58. 

Recent update: Gardasil 9 has received expanded indication which now includes the prevention of oropharyngeal and head and neck cancers caused by HPV types 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52, and 58.

questions.text: Identify a WHO guideline in second stage of labour among the following:

choices.text: Manual support to perineum to maintain flexion of head
Never give warm compress to the perineum

questions.solution:
The practice of guarding the perineum during delivery of the fetal head is a WHO specified guideline, this prevents perineal tear.

The fingers of one hand support the perineum, while the second hand applies pressure to the fetal head to control the speed of crowning.

 

According to the recent guidelines by WHO manual massage and warm compression of perineum are recommended during the second stage of labor.

questions.text: A 30-year-old G3P2 was admitted to the labor room at 34 weeks of gestation in view of  BP - 150/90mmHg and Urine albumin - 2+. Which of the following drugs is not used to control BP in this patient ______
questions.solution:
Captopril is an ACE inhibitor and it is contraindicated in pregnancy.

High BP and proteinuria are diagnostic of pre-eclampsia. Methyl dopa, labetalol, and hydralazine are agents used for the management of pre-eclampsia.

ACE Inhibitor effects on the fetus: These drugs inhibit the conversion of angiotensin I to the potent vasoconstrictor angiotensin-II. They can cause severe fetal malformations when given in the second and third trimesters.

Anti-hypertensives to be avoided in pregnancy:

  • ACE inhibitors
  • Angiotensin receptor blockers 
  • Diuretics (Contraindicated as an anti-hypertensive but can be given in CCF)
  • Reserpine
  • Sodium Nitroprusside (used only as a drug of last resort in refractory severe hypertension)
  • Diazoxide

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy was found to have a height for age 2 standard deviations below the median. Furthermore, his bone age was found to be equal to chronological age. Which of the following is most likely?
questions.solution:
Familial short stature is most likely as bone age is equal to chronological age.

Bone age is more than chronological age in precocious puberty.

Bone age is less than chronological age in all other causes of short stature such as constitutional delay, undernutrition, genetic diseases, and endocrine causes.

Related Pearl: Short stature: Familial vs Constitutional

Feature Constitutional Delay Familial Short Stature  
Height Short Short
Final Height Normal Short  
Family history Delayed puberty Short stature  
Bone age Less than chronological age Normal  
Puberty Delayed Normal  
Height velocity Normal Normal

questions.text: Shepherd's crook deformity is seen in ______
questions.solution:
Shepherd's crook deformity is seen in fibrous dysplasia of proximal femur.

Fibrous dysplasia is a developmental disorder in which area of trabecular bone is replaced by cellular fibrous tissue. If this occurs in the weight-bearing bones like the femur, it will lead to the bending of bones called as ‘Shepherd’s crook' deformity.

Image: Bending of upper femur in fibrous dysplasia known as Shepherd’s crook deformity

questions.text: To diagnose a child with attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder, symptoms should begin before what age?
questions.solution:
To diagnose ADHD, symptoms have to be present before 12 years of age.

According to DSM-5, six or more symptoms of inattention for children up to age 16 years, or five or more symptoms for adolescents age 17 years and older and adults are required to make a diagnosis. Symptoms of inattention/hyperactivity must be present for at least 6 months.

questions.text: A known cardiac patient who underwent PCI with stent placement 6 months ago is on regular aspirin ever since. He is posted for emergency hernia surgery for the strangulated hernia. What would be your advice regarding aspirin?

choices.text: Stop aspirin and replace with heparin
Stop aspirin and give platelet transfusion

questions.solution:
If a patient on a coronary stent taking aspirin is posted for surgery, aspirin should be continued even on the day of surgery to avoid the risk of stent rethrombosis, myocardial infarction or death.

Antiplatelet drugs should not be interrupted in patients with coronary stents without consultation with a cardiologist.

  • Drug-eluting coronary stents require antiplatelet administration for at least 6 months.
  • Bare metal stents for at least one month.

Ideally, elective surgery is avoided for one month in patients with bare coronary stents and one year for those with drug-eluting stents. But emergency surgeries cannot be postponed.

Note: The drug-eluting stents delay this endothelial growth by eluting drugs like sirolimus/paclitaxel etc and thereby reduce the risk of endothelial overgrowth causing occlusion. But this prolonged lack of endothelial lining causes an increased risk of thrombosis and hence a longer duration of antiplatelet therapy is required with drug-eluting stents.

Related Pearl: Drugs that should be discontinued prior to surgery

Drugs that should be discontinued prior to surgery:

Drug Duration before discontinuation

Topical medications

 Discontinue on the day of surgery

Diuretics (except thiazides) 

Discontinue on the day of surgery

Oral hypoglycemic agents 

Discontinue on the day of surgery

Sildenafil 

Discontinue 24 hours before the day of surgery

NSAIDs 

 Discontinue 48 hours before the day of surgery

Warfarin 

Discontinue 4 days before surgery (except for patients having cataract surgery without a bulbar block)

Short-acting Insulins 

 Discontinued (except when given by a continuous pump)

Thienopyridines (e.g., clopidogrel, ticlopidine) 

 Discontinued (Except in cataract surgery, patients with metallic/drug-eluting stents)

Aspirin 

 Discontinued 3 days before the surgery (except in patients with prior PCI, coronary artery disease and stroke)

MAO Inhibitors

 Discontinued 2 weeks prior

questions.text: A male patient presents to your clinic with complaints of a large lesion on the back and left shoulder. There is no pain or itching associated with the lesion. On examination, there is a 15x20 cm hyperpigmented patch with irregular borders over the left shoulder and back, with hair growth over the lesion. The image of the physical examination findings is shown below. When is the onset of the lesion most likely to occur?
questions.solution:
The given stem and image show Becker's Naevus, the onset of which is usually in puberty.

Becker's naevus is an epidermal melanocytic naevus with aggregation of melanocyte clusters in the epidermis beginning in adolescence when there is an increased sensitivity to androgens especially in the distribution of outer arms, scapular area and chest. It is rarely congenital. A triad of features can be seen:

  • Hyperpigmentation
  • Hypertrichosis
  • Acne

Becker naevus can also be associated with extracutaneous abnormalities such as aplasia or hypoplasia of the underlying breast tissue, or pectoralis major muscle or lipoatrophy. In such cases, it is referred to as Becker naevus Syndrome. Other extracutaneous associations include ipsilateral limb growth disturbance, supernumer­ary nipples, and scoliosis.

questions.text: Patient with a metallic foreign body in eye, which of the following investigation is contraindicated?
questions.solution:
MRI is contraindicated in:

  • Cardiac pacemakers (best response)
  • Aneurysmal metallic clips
  • Metallic foreign body
  • Cochlear implant
  • Claustrophobia (relative contraindication)

questions.text: Personal monitoring of radiation is done by:
questions.solution:
Personal monitoring of radiation is done by a TLD badge.

TLD badge (thermoluminescent dosimeter) is made up of Lithium fluoride or calcium sulfate doped with dysprosium.

The badge should be positioned according to local or national practices. In India, one TLD badge has to be worn at the chest level inside the lead apron, if the apron is used. An additional wrist badge has to be worn for procedures requiring hands close to the primary beam. 

The given image shows a TLD badge.
